CONCLUSION: No violation of Art. 3;No violation of Art. 5-1;No violation of Art. 5-3;No violation of Art. 8;Violation of Art. 5-4;Violation of Art. 8;Violation of Art. 10;Not necessary to examine Art. 13;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . Mr PERSON is a NORP citizen who has lived in GPE since DATE . He currently resides in GPE .

CARDINAL . From CARDINAL DATE to CARDINAL DATE he served CARDINAL prison sentences in succession , following convictions pronounced by ORG ( PERSON für PERSON ) and confirmed in part by ORG ) , inter alia for assaults on his wife , clients of his television repair business and public officials .

CARDINAL . The Inner Vienna District Court ( PERSON Innere GPE ) on DATE and ORG ( PERSON für PERSON ) , acting as guardianship court ( GPE ) , on DATE declared the applicant partly incapacitated ( beschränkt entmündigt ) and appointed an adviser ( ORG ) for him . They did so on the basis of a psychiatrist ’s report which had been drawn up following numerous complaints by him about prison conditions .

On DATE ORG appointed a new adviser , who has acted as such since then . According to a ruling of the guardianship court of DATE , his position was equivalent as from DATE to that of a curator ( Sachwalter ) within the meaning of LAW ) , sub - paragraph CARDINAL , of LAW ( see paragraph DATE below ) .
CARDINAL . In the meantime , further prosecutions were brought against Mr Herczegfalvy for assaults on warders and fellow prisoners and for serious threats against judges .

On DATE ORG ordered that once he had finished serving his sentence on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) the applicant should remain in detention under LAW ) , sub - paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL , of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , as there was reason to fear that he might attempt to abscond and might commit other offences . The applicant unsuccessfully appealed to ORG ( Ratskammer ) of ORG and to ORG ( Oberlandesgericht ) , whose rulings were given on DATE and DATE respectively . The pre - trial detention ( Untersuchungshaft ) was confirmed by the presiding judge of ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . In accordance with the opinions of several experts , the presiding judge on DATE ordered Mr ORG ’s provisional placement ( vorläufige Unterbringung ) in an institution for mentally ill offenders ( LAW ; see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The order was confirmed by ORG on DATE and ORG on DATE , and the applicant was transferred to the special prison at GPE , GPE .

CARDINAL . According to the psychiatrists who examined him , he was suffering from paranoia querulans , which was equivalent to a mental illness and meant that he was not responsible for his acts ; he was extremely aggressive and incapable of understanding that his behaviour was unlawful , and there was a risk that attendance at the trial could harm his health .

Following these reports , the public prosecutor ’s office amended the indictment on DATE and now sought PERSON detention rather than conviction . From that date the detention in issue was based on LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The applicant ’s appeal against the amended indictment was dismissed by ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . The hearing before ORG took place on CARDINAL and DATE . It had previously been necessary to adjourn a hearing arranged for DATE because the case - file had been lost , to adjourn a hearing of CARDINAL DATE because of the applicant ’s request for further witnesses to be called , a hearing of DATE because the presiding judge was absent , CARDINAL of DATE because fresh evidence had been produced , CARDINAL of DATE because of mistakes in sending out summonses , and CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE because the applicant had spat in the presiding judge ’s face , which had led to the indictment being amended ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

On DATE the court found that the charges against Mr Herczegfalvy had been proved and ordered him to be detained under LAW ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , on the grounds that he was dangerous and not criminally responsible for his acts . The court relied on the opinions of CARDINAL psychiatrists who had each diagnosed paranoia querulans which from DATE at least had been equivalent to a mental illness .

CARDINAL . The applicant brought an application for a declaration of nullity ( PERSON ) to ORG . ORG decided , however , that pending the decision he should remain provisionally detained under LAW , but in prison , on the psychiatrist ’s recommendation .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , relying on LAW , ordered that the detention should be continued and that the applicant should be transferred as a matter of urgency to a psychiatric hospital , so that the treatment he required could be carried out . PERSON stayed there from DATE to DATE and was then returned to the prison .
ORG , to which the applicant had appealed , held on DATE that it had no jurisdiction : as LAW was the only provision which could apply , it was for ORG to hear the appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the detention in issue . Applying Article CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW , it ordered PERSON to be sent to the GPE psychiatric hospital so that he could receive urgent medical and socio- and psycho - therapeutic treatment there , which was essential inter alia because of the hunger strike he had carried on since DATE . On DATE he was admitted to ward CARDINAL of that hospital , and stayed there until his release on DATE .
The applicant ’s appeal against this decision was dismissed by ORG on DATE .
CARDINAL . In the meantime ORG had on DATE varied the judgment of DATE in part ( see paragraphs CARDINAL above ) , quashed the detention order and remitted the case to ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE Mr ORG requested his release . On DATE the investigating judge informed him that he continued to be detained in accordance with LAW .

At that judge ’s request , the psychiatric hospital submitted a report dated DATE expressing the opinion that it was not possible to place the applicant in ordinary pre - trial detention , as his aggressive behaviour was still causing danger to those around him .
Pursuant to LAW and ORG extended the detention in question in DATE .

CARDINAL . After hearings on DATE and DATE ORG , to which the case had been remitted ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , found that the charges against PERSON which included further serious threats against a judge on DATE - had been proved and ordered him to be detained in an institution for mentally ill offenders under LAW ( CARDINAL ) of LAW . It based its decision on the judgment of DATE , the CARDINAL psychiatric reports on which it had been based ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , and the opinions of the authors of the reports , who had appeared at the hearing and stated that despite certain improvements there had been no fundamental change in the situation .

As the applicant had withdrawn his appeal and application for a declaration of nullity in writing on DATE and at a hearing on DATE , the judgment was on the latter date declared binding by a final order ( Endverfügung ) , which set the date of DATE for the next judicial review of the detention ( LAW ) of LAW ; see paragraph DATE below ) .

The applicant subsequently challenged the validity of his declarations . He said that he had made them only with a view to his repatriation to GPE , which was discussed on DATE but did not come about .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE ORG , acting under LAW ( CARDINAL ) of LAW , extended PERSON detention , as a psychiatric report produced at the request of that court stated that he was a dangerous person . The court took its decision under LAW ) of LAW , after an official of the psychiatric hospital had stated to the court that the DATE review of the lawfulness of the detention should have taken place on DATE at the latest ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE , DATE and a date in DATE the applicant requested his release , pointing out that the period for carrying out the DATE review had expired on CARDINAL DATE . On receiving the first of these applications , the court consulted a psychiatrist , who submitted a report on DATE recommending the applicant ’s release subject to supervision ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

An application to exercise its supervisory jurisdiction ( Dienstaufsichtsbeschwerde ) was made to ORG , which ordered ORG to reach a decision speedily ; on DATE the latter court ordered a further extension of the detention in issue . Taking into account the opinions of the psychiatric expert and the director of the hospital , filed on DATE , it considered that there had been no fundamental change in Mr ORG ’s mental state . He was still suffering from paranoia querulans , and if released would undoubtedly refuse to follow the necessary course of treatment ; he would consequently be likely to bring numerous complaints or even carry out the threats he had made , in particular those against the prison staff ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .
On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal and confirmed that the requirements for his release under LAW ( CARDINAL ) of LAW were not satisfied .

CARDINAL . PERSON made further applications for release on DATE and DATE . He was conditionally released on DATE in accordance with the court ’s decision of DATE , itself based on a psychiatric report dated DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The court found that the applicant ’s paranoia had admittedly worsened , but that it was primarily due to his detention ( Haftquerulanz ) ; the vexatious complaints and petitions ( Rechtsquerulanz ) did not constitute a danger within the meaning of LAW ; since being detained the applicant had behaved with genuine aggressiveness on a few occasions only ; although the possibility could not be excluded of his becoming aggressive in the event of frustration , his psychiatric history did not permit the conclusion that his abnormal personality would induce him to commit criminal offences ; moreover , continued psychiatric treatment or treatment by drugs was not considered necessary by the expert , although it was recommended .

CARDINAL . On being returned to prison after his stay in the GPE psychiatric hospital from DATE to DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , PERSON had begun a hunger strike on DATE as a protest against his detention and the refusal to give him his files . He collapsed on CARDINAL DATE and was transferred to a clinic where he received intensive medical care . On DATE he was transferred back to the GPE psychiatric hospital , where he remained until his release on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . As the applicant was in an extremely weak state when returned there , the director of the hospital ordered him to be force fed , pursuant to section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The applicant refused all contact and refused to have any medical examination or treatment , and was also given sedatives against his will ( CARDINAL doses of QUANTITY each of NORP ) ; on DATE and DATE he was attached to a security bed , the net and straps of which he succeeded in cutting through . On DATE he was given a different neuroleptic ( Sordinol IM ) , as infiltrations had appeared . He stopped refusing food on DATE , after being allocated a single room and being given some of his files .

CARDINAL . Mr Herczegfalvy again went on hunger strike from DATE to CARDINAL DATE , on which date he allegedly eventually agreed to be fed through a tube ( GPE ) once daily . However , he later denied that his consent had been validly given .

CARDINAL . In view of the deterioration of his physical and mental state , he was injected by force with QUANTITY of GPE on DATE , in order to bring about a state of somnolence ( Dämmerschlaf ) in which it would be possible to treat him by means of perfusions . Since he had resisted this with violence , the emergency team had had to overpower him . On DATE he was transferred to the intensive care unit , as he showed symptoms of pneumonia and nephritis ; he stayed there until DATE .

CARDINAL . He had not made a complete recovery when he left , and he still needed treatment with antibiotics and neuroleptics . On his return to the closed unit he was handcuffed and a belt placed around his ankles because of the danger of aggression and the death threats he was making ; the restraints were not removed until DATE . According to the Government , their position was changed regularly , in order to avoid nervous paralysis , and on DATE he had agreed to be fed by a woman doctor . The applicant stated , however , that other belts had been put around his thighs and stomach and had been untied for the first time only on DATE ; in order to obtain his files and writing materials with which to write his complaints , he had continued his hunger strike without interruption , and had been artificially fed throughout this period .

CARDINAL . From CARDINAL DATE the applicant calmed down and behaved in a more co - operative manner . Although he continued to insult the staff from time to time , he agreed to communicate with those around him and consented to being fed through a tube by a female doctor twice DATE . On DATE he was given paper and a ballpoint pen .

CARDINAL . Following a dispute about his correspondence , PERSON was forbidden on DATE to watch television . As his physical resistance to the forced administration of neuroleptics had frequently been in vain and had even led to injuries ( loss of teeth , broken ribs and bruises ) , he brought a complaint of assault on each occasion that he was given medicaments . These letters , which he claimed had not been communicated to the relevant authorities , filled CARDINAL binders ; they were given to him on his discharge .

CARDINAL . During this period he continued to refuse , at least in part , to take nourishment other than through a tube , but on CARDINAL DATE he stated that he no longer needed to be fed artificially , as a doctor had persuaded him to end his hunger strike by explaining to him that it was endangering his life . Hospital reports had , however , stated that he appeared to be adequately nourished .

CARDINAL . In an opinion of CARDINAL DATE an expert considered that conditional release of the applicant would be possible if certain accompanying psychiatric and social measures were taken . In his view , PERSON behaviour was much improved , so that there was now virtually no danger .
CARDINAL . After a further series of complaints which were regarded as vexatious , ORG consulted the hospital on DATE as to the applicant ’s possible release .
On DATE an expert noted the progress which the applicant had made and expressed the opinion that troublesome behaviour did not constitute a risk within the meaning of LAW .

However , in a letter of DATE , the director of the hospital advised the court not to terminate Mr ORG ’s detention ; as the treatment carried out , based on medication , had only a sedative effect , the possibility could not be excluded that if he were released , he would again become aggressive and dangerous .
ORG thereupon on DATE refused to release the applicant ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .
CARDINAL . He eventually recovered his liberty on DATE , after a further expert report dated DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . While in detention PERSON addressed an extremely large number of petitions and complaints to various authorities , relating inter alia to his medical treatment and the proceedings brought by him . As he considered that he did not have the necessary money , he refused on several occasions to put stamps on his letters , or sent them to ORG for that purpose . In order to stem this flow of correspondence , he was deprived from time to time of writing materials , and his unstamped letters were frequently returned to him , with the exception of those addressed to the public authorities , in particular the courts .

CARDINAL . With respect to the letters written at the psychiatric hospital , the hospital management had agreed with the applicant ’s curator that they would be transmitted to him regularly and it would be for him to decide whether it was necessary to send them on ; this system would apply to all letters other than those to his lawyer , his adviser and the guardianship court . PERSON has complained that even those letters were not all sent on .

CARDINAL . When he left the hospital the applicant was given CARDINAL binders containing the originals of these letters and also CARDINAL sealed letters ; the postal register showed that the latter had never been sent to their addressees , namely the police , the public prosecutor ’s office and the courts .

CARDINAL . PERSON also claimed that he had been deprived of reading matter , radio and television for long periods during his detention , in particular from DATE to DATE and from DATE ; from DATE there had been no television set in his cell or in the ward . He alleged that these measures had been taken for disciplinary purposes only .

DATE . According to the Government , these measures were based on section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , had been justified for therapeutic reasons , and had lasted for a short time only on each occasion .

CARDINAL . LAW , in the version in force at the time , permits the pre - trial detention of a person ( where there are serious reasons for suspecting him of having committed a criminal offence ) if there is a danger of absconding , collusion or repetition of offences .

CARDINAL . The risk of absconding can not be presumed if the accused is liable to a penalty of not more than DATE imprisonment , is living in normal conditions and has a permanent address in GPE , unless he has already attempted to abscond ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . The accused can bring an application for release at any time ( LAW ) . Under Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL the request is examined by ORG at a hearing in private , in the presence of the accused or his lawyer . If the accused or the public prosecutor ’s office appeals to ORG , the hearing also takes place in private , in the presence of a member of the principal public prosecutor ’s office , but in the absence of the accused and his lawyer .

If no such application is made by the accused , ORG of its own motion reviews the detention when it has lasted for DATE or where DATE have passed since the last hearing and the accused has no lawyer ( LAW ) .

After the definitive indictment or the fixing of the hearing date for the trial , these review hearings cease . Decisions on the continuation of the detention are now taken by the trial court during the hearing and by ORG , sitting in private , at other times ( LAW .

CARDINAL . Detention on remand is terminated at the latest at the time when a person who has been convicted begins to serve his sentence ; the time spent in detention on remand is automatically deducted from the sentence ( LAW ) .
CARDINAL . In CARDINAL cases specified in ORG CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL of LAW , pre - trial detention may take the form of placement in an institution for mentally ill offenders :

" If CARDINAL of the reasons for detention specified in LAW ) exists , or if the person concerned can not remain at liberty without there being a danger for himself or other persons , or if medical observation of him is necessary , an order shall be made for his provisional detention in an institution for mentally ill offenders or for his admission to a public hospital for mental illnesses ... "

" If there are sufficient reasons for presuming that the conditions in [ LAW are fulfilled , and if reasons for detention ( LAW ) ) exist , but the accused can not without difficulty be detained in the prison of a court , an order shall be made that detention on remand is to take the form of provisional placement in an institution for mentally ill offenders ... "
CARDINAL . Under LAW :

" ( CARDINAL ) If a person commits an offence punishable with a term of imprisonment DATE , and if he can not be punished for the sole reason that he committed the offence under the influence of a state of mind excluding responsibility ( LAW ) resulting from a serious mental or emotional abnormality , the court shall order him to be placed in an institution for mentally ill offenders , if in view of his person , his condition and the nature of the offence it is to be feared that he will otherwise , under the influence of his mental or emotional abnormality , commit a criminal offence with serious consequences .

( CARDINAL ) If such a fear exists , an order for placement in an institution for mentally ill offenders shall also be made in respect of a person who , while not lacking responsibility , commits an offence punishable with a term of imprisonment DATE under the influence of his severe mental or emotional abnormality . In such a case the placement is to be ordered at the same time as the sentence is passed . "
CARDINAL . The duration of these preventive measures is governed by LAW , which states that :
" ( CARDINAL ) Preventive measures are to be ordered for an indefinite period . They are to be implemented for as long as is required by their purpose ...
( CARDINAL ) The termination of preventive measures shall be decided by the court .
( CARDINAL ) The court must of its own motion examine at least once yearly whether the placement in an institution for mentally ill offenders ... is still necessary .
CARDINAL . LAW provides that :

" Pre - trial detention is intended to counteract the dangers specified in LAW . In accordance with the statutory provisions and the regulations based thereon , persons in pre - trial detention may be subjected to restrictions only if they serve the purposes of detention or the maintenance of security or order in the institutions . Prisoners in pre - trial detention are to be treated with calm , seriousness and firmness , in a just manner and with respect for their sense of honour , human dignity and with as little as possible interference with their personality . "
CARDINAL . Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure govern the correspondence of prisoners in pre - trial detention :

" ( CARDINAL ) Prisoners in pre - trial detention may , without prejudice to LAW and sections CARDINAL of ORG , correspond in writing with all persons who are not likely to prejudice the purpose of the pre - trial detention , and to receive visits from such persons .

( CARDINAL ) Correspondence shall not be subject to any restrictions , unless surveillance is prejudiced by the exceptional volume of the correspondence of a prisoner in pre - trial detention . In such a case the restrictions which are necessary for proper surveillance shall be ordered . Letters which are likely to prejudice the purpose of the detention are to be withheld , unless provided otherwise by sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of ORG , relating to written correspondence with official bodies and legal advisers . Letters from prisoners in pre - trial detention which give rise to suspicion that an offence , not being an offence which can be prosecuted only at the request of a person concerned , is being committed by means of them , are always to be stopped , unless they are addressed to a national general representative body , a national court or another national authority , or to ORG .

" Decisions as to which persons prisoners in pre - trial detention may correspond in writing with and which visits they may receive , surveillance of correspondence and visits , and all other orders and decisions relating to contacts between prisoners in pre - trial detention and the outside world ( sections CARDINAL of GPE ) are to be taken by the investigating judge , with the exception of surveillance of parcels . Surveillance of correspondence can be waived only in so far as no prejudice of the purpose of detention is to be feared as a result thereof . "

DATE . Unless provided otherwise , the provisions of ORG ( Strafvollzugsgesetz ) applicable to persons in prison also apply by analogy to persons placed in institutions for mentally ill offenders ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of that law ) . They lay down detailed regulations , for example , with respect to :
- the right to necessary medical treatment ( sections CARDINAL et seq . ) , and compulsory medical treatment and force - feeding ( section CARDINAL ) ;
- the right of access to information by means of books , magazines , newspapers , radio and television ( sections CARDINAL et seq . ) ;

- the right of correspondence , in particular with close relatives and other persons , lawyers , courts and other authorities , representative bodies , the ombudsman , ORG and , in the case of a foreign national , his consulate ( sections CARDINAL et seq . ) ;

- the right to bring petitions and complaints ( sections CARDINAL et seq . ) . Prisoners may submit petitions concerning their conditions of imprisonment ( section CARDINAL ) and complain of actions of the prison staff which in their opinion infringe their rights ( section CARDINAL ) . Complaints are to be addressed to the governor of the prison or , where the complaint is brought against the governor , to ORG ( section CARDINAL ) ; this remains subject to review by ORG and ORG ( Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW ) .

Prisoners may submit petitions and requests , other than those relating to their medical treatment , by means of an application to a higher official , but this does not give the right to an administrative decision ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) , second sentence , and section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) authorises restrictions on the rights of mentally ill offenders only to the extent necessary for the attainment of the purpose of the detention , and prohibits all interferences with their human dignity and with the rights guaranteed them by sections CARDINAL to CARDINAL . It also provides that complaints which have obviously been brought solely because of the detainee ’s mental or emotional disturbance and which are not based on an infringement of his rights shall be rejected without any formal procedure .

CARDINAL . Before the establishment of special institutions for mentally ill offenders , they were placed in closed units of public psychiatric hospitals , regulated by LAW . That law provides inter alia :
" ( CARDINAL ) The medical service must be organised in such a way that medical assistance is always immediately available in the hospital .
( CARDINAL ) Hospital patients may be medically treated only in accordance with the principles and recognised methods of medical science .

( CARDINAL ) Special curative treatments including surgical operations may be carried out on a patient only with his consent , but if the patient has not yet reached DATE or if because he lacks mental maturity or health he can not assess the necessity or usefulness of the treatment , only with the consent of his legal representative . Consent is not required if the treatment is so urgently necessary that the delay involved in obtaining the consent of the patient or his legal representative or in appointing a legal representative would endanger his life or would entail the danger of serious harm to his health . The medical director of the hospital or the doctor responsible for the management of the hospital department concerned shall decide on the necessity and urgency of treatment . "
" Patients who are compulsorily detained ... may be subjected to restrictions with respect to freedom of movement or contact with the outside world . "

CARDINAL . The applicant ’s partial legal incapacitation , which was pronounced in DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , was based on sections CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL of the Incapacitation Regulations ( Entmündigungsordnung ) of DATE :

" Adults who are unable to look after their own affairs and , because of a mental illness or a handicap , need the assistance of an adviser ( ORG ) to look after their affairs appropriately , may be declared partially incapacitated . "
" ( CARDINAL ) A person who is partially incapacitated shall be treated as a minor over DATE ( mündiger PERSON ) and shall be given an adviser .

( CARDINAL ) The adviser shall have the rights and duties of a guardian ( Vormund ) , but the guardianship court may reserve to the adviser the right to dispose over what the incapacitated person acquires by his work . "
CARDINAL . The functions of a guardian are defined in LAW , first sentence , of ORG ) , which reads as follows :
" A guardian must primarily take care of the person of the minor , but also administer his property . "

Article CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) states that if care for the person and education of a minor is not the responsibility of a person having parental authority , the guardian shall have responsibility therefor .

CARDINAL . Under the Law of DATE on the appointment of curators of handicapped persons ( ORG ) , persons who have been declared totally or partly legally incapacitated are to be regarded from DATE as having the assistance of a curator ( Sachwalter ) , empowered under LAW ) , sub - paragraph CARDINAL , of LAW to look after all their affairs .

Under LAW a curator has the same rights and obligations as a guardian , but must also care for the person of a handicapped person , in particular his medical and social treatment , unless a court decides otherwise .

CARDINAL . Any administrative act , including the exercise of direct administrative compulsion against a particular person , may in principle be challenged as to its lawfulness before ORG ( Verwaltungsgerichtshof , LAW ) and as to its constitutionality before ORG Verfassungsgerichtshof , Article CARDINAL ) .
However , there does not appear to be any example in the case - law of such an application against the acts of a psychiatric hospital of the type of those in issue in the present case .
